Literature Review: Negative-sense RNA viruses represent a significant class of pathogens that pose a considerable threat to human health. These viruses, characterized by their genome organization in an orientation antisense to messenger RNA, include notable human pathogens such as influenza viruses, lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV), and Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV). The development of reverse genetic systems has been pivotal in advancing our understanding of these viruses, enabling researchers to manipulate viral genomes and study their replication mechanisms, pathogenesis, and interactions with host cells. This literature review explores the genetic systems developed for these viruses, the creation of reporter strains, and the biological insights gained from their use, as well as potential future applications in therapeutic development. The advent of reverse genetics has revolutionized the study of negative-sense RNA viruses. By allowing the de novo synthesis of infectious viruses from cloned cDNA, these systems have provided a powerful tool for dissecting viral gene function and virus-host interactions. For influenza viruses, reverse genetics has been instrumental in elucidating the roles of viral proteins in replication and pathogenesis, as well as in the development of live attenuated vaccines (Neumann et al., 1999). Similarly, reverse genetic systems for LCMV have shed light on the virus's ability to establish persistent infections and evade host immune responses (Sanchez and de la Torre, 2005). For RVFV, reverse genetics has facilitated the study of viral virulence factors and the development of candidate vaccines (Bouloy and Flick, 2009). The creation of reporter strains of negative-sense RNA viruses has further expanded the utility of reverse genetic systems. By incorporating genes encoding fluorescent or bioluminescent proteins into viral genomes, researchers can visualize viral replication and spread in real-time, both in vitro and in vivo. Fluorescent strains of influenza virus have been used to study viral entry, assembly, and the dynamics of infection in living cells (Manicassamy et al., 2010). Bioluminescent strains of LCMV have provided insights into the spatial and temporal dynamics of viral dissemination and the host immune response (Ziegler et al., 2016). Similarly, reporter strains of RVFV have been employed to investigate viral tropism and the efficacy of antiviral compounds (Wichgers Schreur et al., 2018). The use of reporter viruses has not only enhanced our understanding of viral biology but also holds promise for the development of novel therapeutic strategies. For example, reporter strains can be used to screen for antiviral compounds and to evaluate vaccine efficacy in preclinical models. Furthermore, the ability to track viral infections in real-time offers the potential to identify new targets for therapeutic intervention and to monitor the effectiveness of treatments in vivo. In conclusion, the development of reverse genetic systems and reporter strains has significantly advanced our understanding of negative-sense RNA viruses. These tools have provided valuable insights into viral replication, pathogenesis, and host interactions, and have the potential to inform the development of new antiviral therapies and vaccines. As research in this field continues to evolve, the application of these technologies will undoubtedly contribute to our ability to combat these important human pathogens.
